14#ifndef DNS_MESSAGE_H
15#define DNS_MESSAGE_H 1
16
17/***
18 *** Imports
19 ***/
20
21#include <inttypes.h>
22#include <stdbool.h>
23
24#include <isc/lang.h>
25#include <isc/magic.h>
26
27#include <dns/compress.h>
28#include <dns/masterdump.h>
29#include <dns/types.h>
30
31#include <dst/dst.h>
32
33/*! \file dns/message.h
34 * \brief Message Handling Module
35 *
36 * How this beast works:
37 *
38 * When a dns message is received in a buffer, dns_message_parse() is called
39 * on the memory region. Various items are checked including the format
40 * of the message (if counts are right, if counts consume the entire sections,
41 * and if sections consume the entire message) and known pseudo-RRs in the
42 * additional data section are analyzed and removed.
43 *
44 * TSIG checking is also done at this layer, and any DNSSEC transaction
45 * signatures should also be checked here.
46 *
47 * Notes on using the gettemp*() and puttemp*() functions:
48 *
49 * These functions return items (names, rdatasets, etc) allocated from some
50 * internal state of the dns_message_t.
51 *
52 * Names and rdatasets must be put back into the dns_message_t in
53 * one of two ways. Assume a name was allocated via
54 * dns_message_gettempname():
55 *
56 *\li (1) insert it into a section, using dns_message_addname().
57 *
58 *\li (2) return it to the message using dns_message_puttempname().
59 *
60 * The same applies to rdatasets.
61 *
62 * On the other hand, offsets, rdatalists and rdatas allocated using
63 * dns_message_gettemp*() will always be freed automatically
64 * when the message is reset or destroyed; calling dns_message_puttemp*()
65 * on rdatalists and rdatas is optional and serves only to enable the item
66 * to be reused multiple times during the lifetime of the message; offsets
67 * cannot be reused.
68 *
69 * Buffers allocated using isc_buffer_allocate() can be automatically freed
70 * as well by giving the buffer to the message using dns_message_takebuffer().
71 * Doing this will cause the buffer to be freed using isc_buffer_free()
72 * when the section lists are cleared, such as in a reset or in a destroy.
73 * Since the buffer itself exists until the message is destroyed, this sort
74 * of code can be written:
75 *
76 * \code
77 * buffer = isc_buffer_allocate(mctx, 512);
78 * name = NULL;
79 * name = dns_message_gettempname(message, &name);
80 * dns_name_init(name, NULL);
81 * result = dns_name_fromtext(name, &source, dns_rootname, 0, buffer);
82 * dns_message_takebuffer(message, &buffer);
83 * \endcode
84 *
85 *
86 * TODO:
87 *
88 * XXX Needed: ways to set and retrieve EDNS information, add rdata to a
89 * section, move rdata from one section to another, remove rdata, etc.
90 */
91
92#define DNS_MESSAGEFLAG_QR 0x8000U
93#define DNS_MESSAGEFLAG_AA 0x0400U
94#define DNS_MESSAGEFLAG_TC 0x0200U
95#define DNS_MESSAGEFLAG_RD 0x0100U
96#define DNS_MESSAGEFLAG_RA 0x0080U
97#define DNS_MESSAGEFLAG_AD 0x0020U
98#define DNS_MESSAGEFLAG_CD 0x0010U
99
100/*%< EDNS0 extended message flags */
101#define DNS_MESSAGEEXTFLAG_DO 0x8000U
102
103/*%< EDNS0 extended OPT codes */
104#define DNS_OPT_NSID 3 /*%< NSID opt code */
105#define DNS_OPT_CLIENT_SUBNET 8 /*%< client subnet opt code */
106#define DNS_OPT_EXPIRE 9 /*%< EXPIRE opt code */
107#define DNS_OPT_COOKIE 10 /*%< COOKIE opt code */
108#define DNS_OPT_TCP_KEEPALIVE 11 /*%< TCP keepalive opt code */
109#define DNS_OPT_PAD 12 /*%< PAD opt code */
110#define DNS_OPT_KEY_TAG 14 /*%< Key tag opt code */
111
112/*%< Experimental options [65001...65534] as per RFC6891 */
113
114/*%< The number of EDNS options we know about. */
115#define DNS_EDNSOPTIONS 7
116
117#define DNS_MESSAGE_REPLYPRESERVE (DNS_MESSAGEFLAG_RD|DNS_MESSAGEFLAG_CD)
118#define DNS_MESSAGEEXTFLAG_REPLYPRESERVE (DNS_MESSAGEEXTFLAG_DO)
119
120#define DNS_MESSAGE_HEADERLEN 12 /*%< 6 uint16_t's */
121
122#define DNS_MESSAGE_MAGIC ISC_MAGIC('M','S','G','@')
123#define DNS_MESSAGE_VALID(msg) ISC_MAGIC_VALID(msg, DNS_MESSAGE_MAGIC)
124
125/*
126 * Ordering here matters. DNS_SECTION_ANY must be the lowest and negative,
127 * and DNS_SECTION_MAX must be one greater than the last used section.
128 */
129typedef int dns_section_t;
130#define DNS_SECTION_ANY (-1)
131#define DNS_SECTION_QUESTION 0
132#define DNS_SECTION_ANSWER 1
133#define DNS_SECTION_AUTHORITY 2
134#define DNS_SECTION_ADDITIONAL 3
135#define DNS_SECTION_MAX 4
136
137typedef int dns_pseudosection_t;
138#define DNS_PSEUDOSECTION_ANY (-1)
139#define DNS_PSEUDOSECTION_OPT 0
140#define DNS_PSEUDOSECTION_TSIG 1
141#define DNS_PSEUDOSECTION_SIG0 2
142#define DNS_PSEUDOSECTION_MAX 3
143
144typedef int dns_messagetextflag_t;
145#define DNS_MESSAGETEXTFLAG_NOCOMMENTS 0x0001
146#define DNS_MESSAGETEXTFLAG_NOHEADERS 0x0002
147#define DNS_MESSAGETEXTFLAG_ONESOA 0x0004
148#define DNS_MESSAGETEXTFLAG_OMITSOA 0x0008
149
150/*
151 * Dynamic update names for these sections.
152 */
153#define DNS_SECTION_ZONE DNS_SECTION_QUESTION
154#define DNS_SECTION_PREREQUISITE DNS_SECTION_ANSWER
155#define DNS_SECTION_UPDATE DNS_SECTION_AUTHORITY
156
157/*
158 * These tell the message library how the created dns_message_t will be used.
159 */
160#define DNS_MESSAGE_INTENTUNKNOWN 0 /*%< internal use only */
161#define DNS_MESSAGE_INTENTPARSE 1 /*%< parsing messages */
162#define DNS_MESSAGE_INTENTRENDER 2 /*%< rendering */
163
164/*
165 * Control behavior of parsing
166 */
167#define DNS_MESSAGEPARSE_PRESERVEORDER 0x0001 /*%< preserve rdata order */
168#define DNS_MESSAGEPARSE_BESTEFFORT 0x0002 /*%< return a message if a
169 recoverable parse error
170 occurs */
171#define DNS_MESSAGEPARSE_CLONEBUFFER 0x0004 /*%< save a copy of the
172 source buffer */
173#define DNS_MESSAGEPARSE_IGNORETRUNCATION 0x0008 /*%< truncation errors are
174 * not fatal. */
175
176/*
177 * Control behavior of rendering
178 */
179#define DNS_MESSAGERENDER_ORDERED 0x0001 /*%< don't change order */
180#define DNS_MESSAGERENDER_PARTIAL 0x0002 /*%< allow a partial rdataset */
181#define DNS_MESSAGERENDER_OMITDNSSEC 0x0004 /*%< omit DNSSEC records */
182#define DNS_MESSAGERENDER_PREFER_A 0x0008 /*%< prefer A records in
183 additional section. */
184#define DNS_MESSAGERENDER_PREFER_AAAA 0x0010 /*%< prefer AAAA records in
185 additional section. */
186/* Obsolete: DNS_MESSAGERENDER_FILTER_AAAA 0x0020 */
187
188typedef struct dns_msgblock dns_msgblock_t;
189
190struct dns_sortlist_arg {
191 dns_aclenv_t *env;
192 const dns_acl_t *acl;
193 const dns_aclelement_t *element;
194};
195
196struct dns_message {
197 /* public from here down */
198 unsigned int magic;
199
200 dns_messageid_t id;
201 unsigned int flags;
202 dns_rcode_t rcode;
203 dns_opcode_t opcode;
204 dns_rdataclass_t rdclass;
205
206 /* 4 real, 1 pseudo */
207 unsigned int counts[DNS_SECTION_MAX];
208
209 /* private from here down */
210 dns_namelist_t sections[DNS_SECTION_MAX];
211 dns_name_t *cursors[DNS_SECTION_MAX];
212 dns_rdataset_t *opt;
213 dns_rdataset_t *sig0;
214 dns_rdataset_t *tsig;
215
216 int state;
217 unsigned int from_to_wire : 2;
218 unsigned int header_ok : 1;
219 unsigned int question_ok : 1;
220 unsigned int tcp_continuation : 1;
221 unsigned int verified_sig : 1;
222 unsigned int verify_attempted : 1;
223 unsigned int free_query : 1;
224 unsigned int free_saved : 1;
225 unsigned int cc_ok : 1;
226 unsigned int cc_bad : 1;
227 unsigned int tkey : 1;
228 unsigned int rdclass_set : 1;
229
230 unsigned int opt_reserved;
231 unsigned int sig_reserved;
232 unsigned int reserved; /* reserved space (render) */
233
234 uint16_t padding;
235 unsigned int padding_off;
236
237 isc_buffer_t *buffer;
238 dns_compress_t *cctx;
239
240 isc_mem_t *mctx;
241 isc_mempool_t *namepool;
242 isc_mempool_t *rdspool;
243
244 isc_bufferlist_t scratchpad;
245 isc_bufferlist_t cleanup;
246
247 ISC_LIST(dns_msgblock_t) rdatas;
248 ISC_LIST(dns_msgblock_t) rdatalists;
249 ISC_LIST(dns_msgblock_t) offsets;
250
251 ISC_LIST(dns_rdata_t) freerdata;
252 ISC_LIST(dns_rdatalist_t) freerdatalist;
253
254 dns_rcode_t tsigstatus;
255 dns_rcode_t querytsigstatus;
256 dns_name_t *tsigname; /* Owner name of TSIG, if any */
257 dns_rdataset_t *querytsig;
258 dns_tsigkey_t *tsigkey;
259 dst_context_t *tsigctx;
260 int sigstart;
261 int timeadjust;
262
263 dns_name_t *sig0name; /* Owner name of SIG0, if any */
264 dst_key_t *sig0key;
265 dns_rcode_t sig0status;
266 isc_region_t query;
267 isc_region_t saved;
268
269 dns_rdatasetorderfunc_t order;
270 dns_sortlist_arg_t order_arg;
271};
272
273struct dns_ednsopt {
274 uint16_t code;
275 uint16_t length;
276 unsigned char *value;
277};
278
279/***
280 *** Functions
281 ***/
282
283ISC_LANG_BEGINDECLS
284
285isc_result_t
286dns_message_create(isc_mem_t *mctx, unsigned int intent, dns_message_t **msgp);
287
288/*%<
289 * Create msg structure.
290 *
291 * This function will allocate some internal blocks of memory that are
292 * expected to be needed for parsing or rendering nearly any type of message.
293 *
294 * Requires:
295 *\li 'mctx' be a valid memory context.
296 *
297 *\li 'msgp' be non-null and '*msg' be NULL.
298 *
299 *\li 'intent' must be one of DNS_MESSAGE_INTENTPARSE or
300 * #DNS_MESSAGE_INTENTRENDER.
301 *
302 * Ensures:
303 *\li The data in "*msg" is set to indicate an unused and empty msg
304 * structure.
305 *
306 * Returns:
307 *\li #ISC_R_NOMEMORY -- out of memory
308 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS -- success
309 */
310
311void
312dns_message_reset(dns_message_t *msg, unsigned int intent);
313/*%<
314 * Reset a message structure to default state. All internal lists are freed
315 * or reset to a default state as well. This is simply a more efficient
316 * way to call dns_message_destroy() followed by dns_message_allocate(),
317 * since it avoid many memory allocations.
318 *
319 * If any data loanouts (buffers, names, rdatas, etc) were requested,
320 * the caller must no longer use them after this call.
321 *
322 * The intended next use of the message will be 'intent'.
323 *
324 * Requires:
325 *
326 *\li 'msg' be valid.
327 *
328 *\li 'intent' is DNS_MESSAGE_INTENTPARSE or DNS_MESSAGE_INTENTRENDER
329 */
330
331void
332dns_message_destroy(dns_message_t **msgp);
333/*%<
334 * Destroy all state in the message.
335 *
336 * Requires:
337 *
338 *\li 'msgp' be valid.
339 *
340 * Ensures:
341 *\li '*msgp' == NULL
342 */
343
344isc_result_t
345dns_message_sectiontotext(dns_message_t *msg, dns_section_t section,
346 const dns_master_style_t *style,
347 dns_messagetextflag_t flags,
348 isc_buffer_t *target);
349
350isc_result_t
351dns_message_pseudosectiontotext(dns_message_t *msg,
352 dns_pseudosection_t section,
353 const dns_master_style_t *style,
354 dns_messagetextflag_t flags,
355 isc_buffer_t *target);
356/*%<
357 * Convert section 'section' or 'pseudosection' of message 'msg' to
358 * a cleartext representation
359 *
360 * Notes:
361 * \li See dns_message_totext for meanings of flags.
362 *
363 * Requires:
364 *
365 *\li 'msg' is a valid message.
366 *
367 *\li 'style' is a valid master dump style.
368 *
369 *\li 'target' is a valid buffer.
370 *
371 *\li 'section' is a valid section label.
372 *
373 * Ensures:
374 *
375 *\li If the result is success:
376 * The used space in 'target' is updated.
377 *
378 * Returns:
379 *
380 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS
381 *\li #ISC_R_NOSPACE
382 *\li #ISC_R_NOMORE
383 *
384 *\li Note: On error return, *target may be partially filled with data.
385*/
386
387isc_result_t
388dns_message_totext(dns_message_t *msg, const dns_master_style_t *style,
389 dns_messagetextflag_t flags, isc_buffer_t *target);
390/*%<
391 * Convert all sections of message 'msg' to a cleartext representation
392 *
393 * Notes on flags:
394 *\li If #DNS_MESSAGETEXTFLAG_NOCOMMENTS is cleared, lines beginning with
395 * ";;" will be emitted indicating section name.
396 *\li If #DNS_MESSAGETEXTFLAG_NOHEADERS is cleared, header lines will be
397 * emitted.
398 *\li If #DNS_MESSAGETEXTFLAG_ONESOA is set then only print the first
399 * SOA record in the answer section.
400 *\li If *#DNS_MESSAGETEXTFLAG_OMITSOA is set don't print any SOA records
401 * in the answer section.
402 *
403 * The SOA flags are useful for suppressing the display of the second
404 * SOA record in an AXFR by setting #DNS_MESSAGETEXTFLAG_ONESOA on the
405 * first message in an AXFR stream and #DNS_MESSAGETEXTFLAG_OMITSOA on
406 * subsequent messages.
407 *
408 * Requires:
409 *
410 *\li 'msg' is a valid message.
411 *
412 *\li 'style' is a valid master dump style.
413 *
414 *\li 'target' is a valid buffer.
415 *
416 * Ensures:
417 *
418 *\li If the result is success:
419 * The used space in 'target' is updated.
420 *
421 * Returns:
422 *
423 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS
424 *\li #ISC_R_NOSPACE
425 *\li #ISC_R_NOMORE
426 *
427 *\li Note: On error return, *target may be partially filled with data.
428 */
429
430isc_result_t
431dns_message_parse(dns_message_t *msg, isc_buffer_t *source,
432 unsigned int options);
433/*%<
434 * Parse raw wire data in 'source' as a DNS message.
435 *
436 * OPT records are detected and stored in the pseudo-section "opt".
437 * TSIGs are detected and stored in the pseudo-section "tsig".
438 *
439 * If #DNS_MESSAGEPARSE_PRESERVEORDER is set, or if the opcode of the message
440 * is UPDATE, a separate dns_name_t object will be created for each RR in the
441 * message. Each such dns_name_t will have a single rdataset containing the
442 * single RR, and the order of the RRs in the message is preserved.
443 * Otherwise, only one dns_name_t object will be created for each unique
444 * owner name in the section, and each such dns_name_t will have a list
445 * of rdatasets. To access the names and their data, use
446 * dns_message_firstname() and dns_message_nextname().
447 *
448 * If #DNS_MESSAGEPARSE_BESTEFFORT is set, errors in message content will
449 * not be considered FORMERRs. If the entire message can be parsed, it
450 * will be returned and DNS_R_RECOVERABLE will be returned.
451 *
452 * If #DNS_MESSAGEPARSE_IGNORETRUNCATION is set then return as many complete
453 * RR's as possible, DNS_R_RECOVERABLE will be returned.
454 *
455 * OPT and TSIG records are always handled specially, regardless of the
456 * 'preserve_order' setting.
457 *
458 * Requires:
459 *\li "msg" be valid.
460 *
461 *\li "buffer" be a wire format buffer.
462 *
463 * Ensures:
464 *\li The buffer's data format is correct.
465 *
466 *\li The buffer's contents verify as correct regarding header bits, buffer
467 * and rdata sizes, etc.
468 *
469 * Returns:
470 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS -- all is well
471 *\li #ISC_R_NOMEMORY -- no memory
472 *\li #DNS_R_RECOVERABLE -- the message parsed properly, but contained
473 * errors.
474 *\li Many other errors possible XXXMLG
475 */
476
477isc_result_t
478dns_message_renderbegin(dns_message_t *msg, dns_compress_t *cctx,
479 isc_buffer_t *buffer);
480/*%<
481 * Begin rendering on a message. Only one call can be made to this function
482 * per message.
483 *
484 * The compression context is "owned" by the message library until
485 * dns_message_renderend() is called. It must be invalidated by the caller.
486 *
487 * The buffer is "owned" by the message library until dns_message_renderend()
488 * is called.
489 *
490 * Requires:
491 *
492 *\li 'msg' be valid.
493 *
494 *\li 'cctx' be valid.
495 *
496 *\li 'buffer' is a valid buffer.
497 *
498 * Side Effects:
499 *
500 *\li The buffer is cleared before it is used.
501 *
502 * Returns:
503 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS -- all is well
504 *\li #ISC_R_NOSPACE -- output buffer is too small
505 */
506
507isc_result_t
508dns_message_renderchangebuffer(dns_message_t *msg, isc_buffer_t *buffer);
509/*%<
510 * Reset the buffer. This can be used after growing the old buffer
511 * on a ISC_R_NOSPACE return from most of the render functions.
512 *
513 * On successful completion, the old buffer is no longer used by the
514 * library. The new buffer is owned by the library until
515 * dns_message_renderend() is called.
516 *
517 * Requires:
518 *
519 *\li 'msg' be valid.
520 *
521 *\li dns_message_renderbegin() was called.
522 *
523 *\li buffer != NULL.
524 *
525 * Returns:
526 *\li #ISC_R_NOSPACE -- new buffer is too small
527 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS -- all is well.
528 */
529
530isc_result_t
531dns_message_renderreserve(dns_message_t *msg, unsigned int space);
532/*%<
533 * XXXMLG should use size_t rather than unsigned int once the buffer
534 * API is cleaned up
535 *
536 * Reserve "space" bytes in the given buffer.
537 *
538 * Requires:
539 *
540 *\li 'msg' be valid.
541 *
542 *\li dns_message_renderbegin() was called.
543 *
544 * Returns:
545 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS -- all is well.
546 *\li #ISC_R_NOSPACE -- not enough free space in the buffer.
547 */
548
549void
550dns_message_renderrelease(dns_message_t *msg, unsigned int space);
551/*%<
552 * XXXMLG should use size_t rather than unsigned int once the buffer
553 * API is cleaned up
554 *
555 * Release "space" bytes in the given buffer that was previously reserved.
556 *
557 * Requires:
558 *
559 *\li 'msg' be valid.
560 *
561 *\li 'space' is less than or equal to the total amount of space reserved
562 * via prior calls to dns_message_renderreserve().
563 *
564 *\li dns_message_renderbegin() was called.
565 */
566
567isc_result_t
568dns_message_rendersection(dns_message_t *msg, dns_section_t section,
569 unsigned int options);
570/*%<
571 * Render all names, rdatalists, etc from the given section at the
572 * specified priority or higher.
573 *
574 * Requires:
575 *\li 'msg' be valid.
576 *
577 *\li 'section' be a valid section.
578 *
579 *\li dns_message_renderbegin() was called.
580 *
581 * Returns:
582 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS -- all records were written, and there are
583 * no more records for this section.
584 *\li #ISC_R_NOSPACE -- Not enough room in the buffer to write
585 * all records requested.
586 *\li #DNS_R_MOREDATA -- All requested records written, and there
587 * are records remaining for this section.
588 */
589
590void
591dns_message_renderheader(dns_message_t *msg, isc_buffer_t *target);
592/*%<
593 * Render the message header. This is implicitly called by
594 * dns_message_renderend().
595 *
596 * Requires:
597 *
598 *\li 'msg' be a valid message.
599 *
600 *\li dns_message_renderbegin() was called.
601 *
602 *\li 'target' is a valid buffer with enough space to hold a message header
603 */
604
605isc_result_t
606dns_message_renderend(dns_message_t *msg);
607/*%<
608 * Finish rendering to the buffer. Note that more data can be in the
609 * 'msg' structure. Destroying the structure will free this, or in a multi-
610 * part EDNS1 message this data can be rendered to another buffer later.
611 *
612 * Requires:
613 *
614 *\li 'msg' be a valid message.
615 *
616 *\li dns_message_renderbegin() was called.
617 *
618 * Returns:
619 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS -- all is well.
620 */
621
622void
623dns_message_renderreset(dns_message_t *msg);
624/*%<
625 * Reset the message so that it may be rendered again.
626 *
627 * Notes:
628 *
629 *\li If dns_message_renderbegin() has been called, dns_message_renderend()
630 * must be called before calling this function.
631 *
632 * Requires:
633 *
634 *\li 'msg' be a valid message with rendering intent.
635 */
636
637isc_result_t
638dns_message_firstname(dns_message_t *msg, dns_section_t section);
639/*%<
640 * Set internal per-section name pointer to the beginning of the section.
641 *
642 * The functions dns_message_firstname() and dns_message_nextname() may
643 * be used for iterating over the owner names in a section.
644 *
645 * Requires:
646 *
647 *\li 'msg' be valid.
648 *
649 *\li 'section' be a valid section.
650 *
651 * Returns:
652 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS -- All is well.
653 *\li #ISC_R_NOMORE -- No names on given section.
654 */
655
656isc_result_t
657dns_message_nextname(dns_message_t *msg, dns_section_t section);
658/*%<
659 * Sets the internal per-section name pointer to point to the next name
660 * in that section.
661 *
662 * Requires:
663 *
664 * \li 'msg' be valid.
665 *
666 *\li 'section' be a valid section.
667 *
668 *\li dns_message_firstname() must have been called on this section,
669 * and the result was ISC_R_SUCCESS.
670 *
671 * Returns:
672 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS -- All is well.
673 *\li #ISC_R_NOMORE -- No more names in given section.
674 */
675
676void
677dns_message_currentname(dns_message_t *msg, dns_section_t section,
678 dns_name_t **name);
679/*%<
680 * Sets 'name' to point to the name where the per-section internal name
681 * pointer is currently set.
682 *
683 * This function returns the name in the database, so any data associated
684 * with it (via the name's "list" member) contains the actual rdatasets.
685 *
686 * Requires:
687 *
688 *\li 'msg' be valid.
689 *
690 *\li 'name' be non-NULL, and *name be NULL.
691 *
692 *\li 'section' be a valid section.
693 *
694 *\li dns_message_firstname() must have been called on this section,
695 * and the result of it and any dns_message_nextname() calls was
696 * #ISC_R_SUCCESS.
697 */
698
699isc_result_t
700dns_message_findname(dns_message_t *msg, dns_section_t section,
701 const dns_name_t *target, dns_rdatatype_t type,
702 dns_rdatatype_t covers, dns_name_t **foundname,
703 dns_rdataset_t **rdataset);
704/*%<
705 * Search for a name in the specified section. If it is found, *name is
706 * set to point to the name, and *rdataset is set to point to the found
707 * rdataset (if type is specified as other than dns_rdatatype_any).
708 *
709 * Requires:
710 *\li 'msg' be valid.
711 *
712 *\li 'section' be a valid section.
713 *
714 *\li If a pointer to the name is desired, 'foundname' should be non-NULL.
715 * If it is non-NULL, '*foundname' MUST be NULL.
716 *
717 *\li If a type other than dns_datatype_any is searched for, 'rdataset'
718 * may be non-NULL, '*rdataset' be NULL, and will point at the found
719 * rdataset. If the type is dns_datatype_any, 'rdataset' must be NULL.
720 *
721 *\li 'target' be a valid name.
722 *
723 *\li 'type' be a valid type.
724 *
725 *\li If 'type' is dns_rdatatype_rrsig, 'covers' must be a valid type.
726 * Otherwise it should be 0.
727 *
728 * Returns:
729 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS -- all is well.
730 *\li #DNS_R_NXDOMAIN -- name does not exist in that section.
731 *\li #DNS_R_NXRRSET -- The name does exist, but the desired
732 * type does not.
733 */
734
735isc_result_t
736dns_message_findtype(const dns_name_t *name, dns_rdatatype_t type,
737 dns_rdatatype_t covers, dns_rdataset_t **rdataset);
738/*%<
739 * Search the name for the specified type. If it is found, *rdataset is
740 * filled in with a pointer to that rdataset.
741 *
742 * Requires:
743 *\li if '**rdataset' is non-NULL, *rdataset needs to be NULL.
744 *
745 *\li 'type' be a valid type, and NOT dns_rdatatype_any.
746 *
747 *\li If 'type' is dns_rdatatype_rrsig, 'covers' must be a valid type.
748 * Otherwise it should be 0.
749 *
750 * Returns:
751 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS -- all is well.
752 *\li #ISC_R_NOTFOUND -- the desired type does not exist.
753 */
754
755isc_result_t
756dns_message_find(const dns_name_t *name, dns_rdataclass_t rdclass,
757 dns_rdatatype_t type, dns_rdatatype_t covers,
758 dns_rdataset_t **rdataset);
759/*%<
760 * Search the name for the specified rdclass and type. If it is found,
761 * *rdataset is filled in with a pointer to that rdataset.
762 *
763 * Requires:
764 *\li if '**rdataset' is non-NULL, *rdataset needs to be NULL.
765 *
766 *\li 'type' be a valid type, and NOT dns_rdatatype_any.
767 *
768 *\li If 'type' is dns_rdatatype_rrsig, 'covers' must be a valid type.
769 * Otherwise it should be 0.
770 *
771 * Returns:
772 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS -- all is well.
773 *\li #ISC_R_NOTFOUND -- the desired type does not exist.
774 */
775
776void
777dns_message_movename(dns_message_t *msg, dns_name_t *name,
778 dns_section_t fromsection,
779 dns_section_t tosection);
780/*%<
781 * Move a name from one section to another.
782 *
783 * Requires:
784 *
785 *\li 'msg' be valid.
786 *
787 *\li 'name' must be a name already in 'fromsection'.
788 *
789 *\li 'fromsection' must be a valid section.
790 *
791 *\li 'tosection' must be a valid section.
792 */
793
794void
795dns_message_addname(dns_message_t *msg, dns_name_t *name,
796 dns_section_t section);
797/*%<
798 * Adds the name to the given section.
799 *
800 * It is the caller's responsibility to enforce any unique name requirements
801 * in a section.
802 *
803 * Requires:
804 *
805 *\li 'msg' be valid, and be a renderable message.
806 *
807 *\li 'name' be a valid absolute name.
808 *
809 *\li 'section' be a named section.
810 */
811
812void
813dns_message_removename(dns_message_t *msg, dns_name_t *name,
814 dns_section_t section);
815/*%<
816 * Remove a existing name from a given section.
817 *
818 * It is the caller's responsibility to ensure the name is part of the
819 * given section.
820 *
821 * Requires:
822 *
823 *\li 'msg' be valid, and be a renderable message.
824 *
825 *\li 'name' be a valid absolute name.
826 *
827 *\li 'section' be a named section.
828 */
829
830
831/*
832 * LOANOUT FUNCTIONS
833 *
834 * Each of these functions loan a particular type of data to the caller.
835 * The storage for these will vanish when the message is destroyed or
836 * reset, and must NOT be used after these operations.
837 */
838
839isc_result_t
840dns_message_gettempname(dns_message_t *msg, dns_name_t **item);
841/*%<
842 * Return a name that can be used for any temporary purpose, including
843 * inserting into the message's linked lists. The name must be returned
844 * to the message code using dns_message_puttempname() or inserted into
845 * one of the message's sections before the message is destroyed.
846 *
847 * It is the caller's responsibility to initialize this name.
848 *
849 * Requires:
850 *\li msg be a valid message
851 *
852 *\li item != NULL && *item == NULL
853 *
854 * Returns:
855 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS -- All is well.
856 *\li #ISC_R_NOMEMORY -- No item can be allocated.
857 */
858
859isc_result_t
860dns_message_gettempoffsets(dns_message_t *msg, dns_offsets_t **item);
861/*%<
862 * Return an offsets array that can be used for any temporary purpose,
863 * such as attaching to a temporary name. The offsets will be freed
864 * when the message is destroyed or reset.
865 *
866 * Requires:
867 *\li msg be a valid message
868 *
869 *\li item != NULL && *item == NULL
870 *
871 * Returns:
872 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS -- All is well.
873 *\li #ISC_R_NOMEMORY -- No item can be allocated.
874 */
875
876isc_result_t
877dns_message_gettemprdata(dns_message_t *msg, dns_rdata_t **item);
878/*%<
879 * Return a rdata that can be used for any temporary purpose, including
880 * inserting into the message's linked lists. The rdata will be freed
881 * when the message is destroyed or reset.
882 *
883 * Requires:
884 *\li msg be a valid message
885 *
886 *\li item != NULL && *item == NULL
887 *
888 * Returns:
889 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS -- All is well.
890 *\li #ISC_R_NOMEMORY -- No item can be allocated.
891 */
892
893isc_result_t
894dns_message_gettemprdataset(dns_message_t *msg, dns_rdataset_t **item);
895/*%<
896 * Return a rdataset that can be used for any temporary purpose, including
897 * inserting into the message's linked lists. The name must be returned
898 * to the message code using dns_message_puttempname() or inserted into
899 * one of the message's sections before the message is destroyed.
900 *
901 * Requires:
902 *\li msg be a valid message
903 *
904 *\li item != NULL && *item == NULL
905 *
906 * Returns:
907 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS -- All is well.
908 *\li #ISC_R_NOMEMORY -- No item can be allocated.
909 */
910
911isc_result_t
912dns_message_gettemprdatalist(dns_message_t *msg, dns_rdatalist_t **item);
913/*%<
914 * Return a rdatalist that can be used for any temporary purpose, including
915 * inserting into the message's linked lists. The rdatalist will be
916 * destroyed when the message is destroyed or reset.
917 *
918 * Requires:
919 *\li msg be a valid message
920 *
921 *\li item != NULL && *item == NULL
922 *
923 * Returns:
924 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS -- All is well.
925 *\li #ISC_R_NOMEMORY -- No item can be allocated.
926 */
927
928void
929dns_message_puttempname(dns_message_t *msg, dns_name_t **item);
930/*%<
931 * Return a borrowed name to the message's name free list.
932 *
933 * Requires:
934 *\li msg be a valid message
935 *
936 *\li item != NULL && *item point to a name returned by
937 * dns_message_gettempname()
938 *
939 * Ensures:
940 *\li *item == NULL
941 */
942
943void
944dns_message_puttemprdata(dns_message_t *msg, dns_rdata_t **item);
945/*%<
946 * Return a borrowed rdata to the message's rdata free list.
947 *
948 * Requires:
949 *\li msg be a valid message
950 *
951 *\li item != NULL && *item point to a rdata returned by
952 * dns_message_gettemprdata()
953 *
954 * Ensures:
955 *\li *item == NULL
956 */
957
958void
959dns_message_puttemprdataset(dns_message_t *msg, dns_rdataset_t **item);
960/*%<
961 * Return a borrowed rdataset to the message's rdataset free list.
962 *
963 * Requires:
964 *\li msg be a valid message
965 *
966 *\li item != NULL && *item point to a rdataset returned by
967 * dns_message_gettemprdataset()
968 *
969 * Ensures:
970 *\li *item == NULL
971 */
972
973void
974dns_message_puttemprdatalist(dns_message_t *msg, dns_rdatalist_t **item);
975/*%<
976 * Return a borrowed rdatalist to the message's rdatalist free list.
977 *
978 * Requires:
979 *\li msg be a valid message
980 *
981 *\li item != NULL && *item point to a rdatalist returned by
982 * dns_message_gettemprdatalist()
983 *
984 * Ensures:
985 *\li *item == NULL
986 */
987
988isc_result_t
989dns_message_peekheader(isc_buffer_t *source, dns_messageid_t *idp,
990 unsigned int *flagsp);
991/*%<
992 * Assume the remaining region of "source" is a DNS message. Peek into
993 * it and fill in "*idp" with the message id, and "*flagsp" with the flags.
994 *
995 * Requires:
996 *
997 *\li source != NULL
998 *
999 * Ensures:
1000 *
1001 *\li if (idp != NULL) *idp == message id.
1002 *
1003 *\li if (flagsp != NULL) *flagsp == message flags.
1004 *
1005 * Returns:
1006 *
1007 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS -- all is well.
1008 *
1009 *\li #ISC_R_UNEXPECTEDEND -- buffer doesn't contain enough for a header.
1010 */
1011
1012isc_result_t
1013dns_message_reply(dns_message_t *msg, bool want_question_section);
1014/*%<
1015 * Start formatting a reply to the query in 'msg'.
1016 *
1017 * Requires:
1018 *
1019 *\li 'msg' is a valid message with parsing intent, and contains a query.
1020 *
1021 * Ensures:
1022 *
1023 *\li The message will have a rendering intent. If 'want_question_section'
1024 * is true, the message opcode is query or notify, and the question
1025 * section is present and properly formatted, then the question section
1026 * will be included in the reply. All other sections will be cleared.
1027 * The QR flag will be set, the RD flag will be preserved, and all other
1028 * flags will be cleared.
1029 *
1030 * Returns:
1031 *
1032 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS -- all is well.
1033 *
1034 *\li #DNS_R_FORMERR -- the header or question section of the
1035 * message is invalid, replying is impossible.
1036 * If DNS_R_FORMERR is returned when
1037 * want_question_section is false, then
1038 * it's the header section that's bad;
1039 * otherwise either of the header or question
1040 * sections may be bad.
1041 */
1042
1043dns_rdataset_t *
1044dns_message_getopt(dns_message_t *msg);
1045/*%<
1046 * Get the OPT record for 'msg'.
1047 *
1048 * Requires:
1049 *
1050 *\li 'msg' is a valid message.
1051 *
1052 * Returns:
1053 *
1054 *\li The OPT rdataset of 'msg', or NULL if there isn't one.
1055 */
1056
1057isc_result_t
1058dns_message_setopt(dns_message_t *msg, dns_rdataset_t *opt);
1059/*%<
1060 * Set the OPT record for 'msg'.
1061 *
1062 * Requires:
1063 *
1064 *\li 'msg' is a valid message with rendering intent
1065 * and no sections have been rendered.
1066 *
1067 *\li 'opt' is a valid OPT record.
1068 *
1069 * Ensures:
1070 *
1071 *\li The OPT record has either been freed or ownership of it has
1072 * been transferred to the message.
1073 *
1074 *\li If ISC_R_SUCCESS was returned, the OPT record will be rendered
1075 * when dns_message_renderend() is called.
1076 *
1077 * Returns:
1078 *
1079 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS -- all is well.
1080 *
1081 *\li #ISC_R_NOSPACE -- there is no space for the OPT record.
1082 */
1083
1084dns_rdataset_t *
1085dns_message_gettsig(dns_message_t *msg, const dns_name_t **owner);
1086/*%<
1087 * Get the TSIG record and owner for 'msg'.
1088 *
1089 * Requires:
1090 *
1091 *\li 'msg' is a valid message.
1092 *\li 'owner' is NULL or *owner is NULL.
1093 *
1094 * Returns:
1095 *
1096 *\li The TSIG rdataset of 'msg', or NULL if there isn't one.
1097 *
1098 * Ensures:
1099 *
1100 * \li If 'owner' is not NULL, it will point to the owner name.
1101 */
1102
1103isc_result_t
1104dns_message_settsigkey(dns_message_t *msg, dns_tsigkey_t *key);
1105/*%<
1106 * Set the tsig key for 'msg'. This is only necessary for when rendering a
1107 * query or parsing a response. The key (if non-NULL) is attached to, and
1108 * will be detached when the message is destroyed.
1109 *
1110 * Requires:
1111 *
1112 *\li 'msg' is a valid message with rendering intent,
1113 * dns_message_renderbegin() has been called, and no sections have been
1114 * rendered.
1115 *\li 'key' is a valid tsig key or NULL.
1116 *
1117 * Returns:
1118 *
1119 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS -- all is well.
1120 *
1121 *\li #ISC_R_NOSPACE -- there is no space for the TSIG record.
1122 */
1123
1124dns_tsigkey_t *
1125dns_message_gettsigkey(dns_message_t *msg);
1126/*%<
1127 * Gets the tsig key for 'msg'.
1128 *
1129 * Requires:
1130 *
1131 *\li 'msg' is a valid message
1132 */
1133
1134isc_result_t
1135dns_message_setquerytsig(dns_message_t *msg, isc_buffer_t *querytsig);
1136/*%<
1137 * Indicates that 'querytsig' is the TSIG from the signed query for which
1138 * 'msg' is the response. This is also used for chained TSIGs in TCP
1139 * responses.
1140 *
1141 * Requires:
1142 *
1143 *\li 'querytsig' is a valid buffer as returned by dns_message_getquerytsig()
1144 * or NULL
1145 *
1146 *\li 'msg' is a valid message
1147 *
1148 * Returns:
1149 *
1150 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS
1151 *\li #ISC_R_NOMEMORY
1152 */
1153
1154isc_result_t
1155dns_message_getquerytsig(dns_message_t *msg, isc_mem_t *mctx,
1156 isc_buffer_t **querytsig);
1157/*%<
1158 * Gets the tsig from the TSIG from the signed query 'msg'. This is also used
1159 * for chained TSIGs in TCP responses. Unlike dns_message_gettsig, this makes
1160 * a copy of the data, so can be used if the message is destroyed.
1161 *
1162 * Requires:
1163 *
1164 *\li 'msg' is a valid signed message
1165 *\li 'mctx' is a valid memory context
1166 *\li querytsig != NULL && *querytsig == NULL
1167 *
1168 * Returns:
1169 *
1170 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS
1171 *\li #ISC_R_NOMEMORY
1172 *
1173 * Ensures:
1174 *\li 'tsig' points to NULL or an allocated buffer which must be freed
1175 * by the caller.
1176 */
1177
1178dns_rdataset_t *
1179dns_message_getsig0(dns_message_t *msg, const dns_name_t **owner);
1180/*%<
1181 * Get the SIG(0) record and owner for 'msg'.
1182 *
1183 * Requires:
1184 *
1185 *\li 'msg' is a valid message.
1186 *\li 'owner' is NULL or *owner is NULL.
1187 *
1188 * Returns:
1189 *
1190 *\li The SIG(0) rdataset of 'msg', or NULL if there isn't one.
1191 *
1192 * Ensures:
1193 *
1194 * \li If 'owner' is not NULL, it will point to the owner name.
1195 */
1196
1197isc_result_t
1198dns_message_setsig0key(dns_message_t *msg, dst_key_t *key);
1199/*%<
1200 * Set the SIG(0) key for 'msg'.
1201 *
1202 * Requires:
1203 *
1204 *\li 'msg' is a valid message with rendering intent,
1205 * dns_message_renderbegin() has been called, and no sections have been
1206 * rendered.
1207 *\li 'key' is a valid sig key or NULL.
1208 *
1209 * Returns:
1210 *
1211 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS -- all is well.
1212 *
1213 *\li #ISC_R_NOSPACE -- there is no space for the SIG(0) record.
1214 */
1215
1216dst_key_t *
1217dns_message_getsig0key(dns_message_t *msg);
1218/*%<
1219 * Gets the SIG(0) key for 'msg'.
1220 *
1221 * Requires:
1222 *
1223 *\li 'msg' is a valid message
1224 */
1225
1226void
1227dns_message_takebuffer(dns_message_t *msg, isc_buffer_t **buffer);
1228/*%<
1229 * Give the *buffer to the message code to clean up when it is no
1230 * longer needed. This is usually when the message is reset or
1231 * destroyed.
1232 *
1233 * Requires:
1234 *
1235 *\li msg be a valid message.
1236 *
1237 *\li buffer != NULL && *buffer is a valid isc_buffer_t, which was
1238 * dynamically allocated via isc_buffer_allocate().
1239 */
1240
1241isc_result_t
1242dns_message_signer(dns_message_t *msg, dns_name_t *signer);
1243/*%<
1244 * If this message was signed, return the identity of the signer.
1245 * Unless ISC_R_NOTFOUND is returned, signer will reflect the name of the
1246 * key that signed the message.
1247 *
1248 * Requires:
1249 *
1250 *\li msg is a valid parsed message.
1251 *\li signer is a valid name
1252 *
1253 * Returns:
1254 *
1255 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS - the message was signed, and *signer
1256 * contains the signing identity
1257 *
1258 *\li #ISC_R_NOTFOUND - no TSIG or SIG(0) record is present in the
1259 * message
1260 *
1261 *\li #DNS_R_TSIGVERIFYFAILURE - the message was signed by a TSIG, but the
1262 * signature failed to verify
1263 *
1264 *\li #DNS_R_TSIGERRORSET - the message was signed by a TSIG and
1265 * verified, but the query was rejected by
1266 * the server
1267 *
1268 *\li #DNS_R_NOIDENTITY - the message was signed by a TSIG and
1269 * verified, but the key has no identity since
1270 * it was generated by an unsigned TKEY process
1271 *
1272 *\li #DNS_R_SIGINVALID - the message was signed by a SIG(0), but
1273 * the signature failed to verify
1274 *
1275 *\li #DNS_R_NOTVERIFIEDYET - the message was signed by a TSIG or SIG(0),
1276 * but the signature has not been verified yet
1277 */
1278
1279isc_result_t
1280dns_message_checksig(dns_message_t *msg, dns_view_t *view);
1281/*%<
1282 * If this message was signed, verify the signature.
1283 *
1284 * Requires:
1285 *
1286 *\li msg is a valid parsed message.
1287 *\li view is a valid view or NULL
1288 *
1289 * Returns:
1290 *
1291 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS - the message was unsigned, or the message
1292 * was signed correctly.
1293 *
1294 *\li #DNS_R_EXPECTEDTSIG - A TSIG was expected, but not seen
1295 *\li #DNS_R_UNEXPECTEDTSIG - A TSIG was seen but not expected
1296 *\li #DNS_R_TSIGVERIFYFAILURE - The TSIG failed to verify
1297 */
1298
1299isc_result_t
1300dns_message_rechecksig(dns_message_t *msg, dns_view_t *view);
1301/*%<
1302 * Reset the signature state and then if the message was signed,
1303 * verify the message.
1304 *
1305 * Requires:
1306 *
1307 *\li msg is a valid parsed message.
1308 *\li view is a valid view or NULL
1309 *
1310 * Returns:
1311 *
1312 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS - the message was unsigned, or the message
1313 * was signed correctly.
1314 *
1315 *\li #DNS_R_EXPECTEDTSIG - A TSIG was expected, but not seen
1316 *\li #DNS_R_UNEXPECTEDTSIG - A TSIG was seen but not expected
1317 *\li #DNS_R_TSIGVERIFYFAILURE - The TSIG failed to verify
1318 */
1319
1320void
1321dns_message_resetsig(dns_message_t *msg);
1322/*%<
1323 * Reset the signature state.
1324 *
1325 * Requires:
1326 *\li 'msg' is a valid parsed message.
1327 */
1328
1329isc_region_t *
1330dns_message_getrawmessage(dns_message_t *msg);
1331/*%<
1332 * Retrieve the raw message in compressed wire format. The message must
1333 * have been successfully parsed for it to have been saved.
1334 *
1335 * Requires:
1336 *\li msg is a valid parsed message.
1337 *
1338 * Returns:
1339 *\li NULL if there is no saved message.
1340 * a pointer to a region which refers the dns message.
1341 */
1342
1343void
1344dns_message_setsortorder(dns_message_t *msg, dns_rdatasetorderfunc_t order,
1345 dns_aclenv_t *env, const dns_acl_t *acl,
1346 const dns_aclelement_t *element);
1347/*%<
1348 * Define the order in which RR sets get rendered by
1349 * dns_message_rendersection() to be the ascending order
1350 * defined by the integer value returned by 'order' when
1351 * given each RR and a ns_sortlist_arg_t constructed from 'env',
1352 * 'acl', and 'element' as arguments.
1353 *
1354 * If 'order' is NULL, a default order is used.
1355 *
1356 * Requires:
1357 *\li msg be a valid message.
1358 *\li If 'env' is NULL, 'order' must be NULL.
1359 *\li If 'env' is not NULL, 'order' must not be NULL and at least one of
1360 * 'acl' and 'element' must also not be NULL.
1361 */
1362
1363void
1364dns_message_settimeadjust(dns_message_t *msg, int timeadjust);
1365/*%<
1366 * Adjust the time used to sign/verify a message by timeadjust.
1367 * Currently only TSIG.
1368 *
1369 * Requires:
1370 *\li msg be a valid message.
1371 */
1372
1373int
1374dns_message_gettimeadjust(dns_message_t *msg);
1375/*%<
1376 * Return the current time adjustment.
1377 *
1378 * Requires:
1379 *\li msg be a valid message.
1380 */
1381
1382void
1383dns_message_logpacket(dns_message_t *message,
1384 const char *description, const isc_sockaddr_t *address,
1385 isc_logcategory_t *category, isc_logmodule_t *module,
1386 int level, isc_mem_t *mctx);
1387
1388void
1389dns_message_logfmtpacket(dns_message_t *message, const char *description,
1390 const isc_sockaddr_t *address,
1391 isc_logcategory_t *category, isc_logmodule_t *module,
1392 const dns_master_style_t *style, int level,
1393 isc_mem_t *mctx);
1394/*%<
1395 * Log 'message' at the specified logging parameters.
1396 *
1397 * For dns_message_logpacket and dns_message_logfmtpacket expect the
1398 * 'description' to end in a newline.
1399 *
1400 * For dns_message_logpacket2 and dns_message_logfmtpacket2
1401 * 'description' will be emitted at the start of the message followed
1402 * by the formatted address and a newline.
1403 *
1404 * Requires:
1405 * \li message be a valid.
1406 * \li description to be non NULL.
1407 * \li address to be non NULL.
1408 * \li category to be valid.
1409 * \li module to be valid.
1410 * \li style to be valid.
1411 * \li mctx to be a valid.
1412 */
1413
1414isc_result_t
1415dns_message_buildopt(dns_message_t *msg, dns_rdataset_t **opt,
1416 unsigned int version, uint16_t udpsize,
1417 unsigned int flags, dns_ednsopt_t *ednsopts, size_t count);
1418/*%<
1419 * Built a opt record.
1420 *
1421 * Requires:
1422 * \li msg be a valid message.
1423 * \li opt to be a non NULL and *opt to be NULL.
1424 *
1425 * Returns:
1426 * \li ISC_R_SUCCESS on success.
1427 * \li ISC_R_NOMEMORY
1428 * \li ISC_R_NOSPACE
1429 * \li other.
1430 */
1431
1432void
1433dns_message_setclass(dns_message_t *msg, dns_rdataclass_t rdclass);
1434/*%<
1435 * Set the expected class of records in the response.
1436 *
1437 * Requires:
1438 * \li msg be a valid message with parsing intent.
1439 */
1440
1441void
1442dns_message_setpadding(dns_message_t *msg, uint16_t padding);
1443/*%<
1444 * Set the padding block size in the response.
1445 * 0 means no padding (default).
1446 *
1447 * Requires:
1448 * \li msg be a valid message.
1449 */
1450
1451ISC_LANG_ENDDECLS
1452
1453#endif /* DNS_MESSAGE_H */
